title: The award-winning wine makers you may not have heard of
text:
Having now tasted all three – very good – limited-release wines in the current Henskens Rankin range, the one that really intrigues me is the Triple Wild (see review, below).

In 2014, Henskens secured some top chardonnay grapes to make a blanc de blancs-style sparkling. Rather than inoculate the juice with yeast and bacteria for primary alcoholic and malolactic fermentation, and then add more yeast for the secondary fermentation in the bottle – common techniques for most sparkling winemakers – Henskens allowed wild microbes on the fruit and in the winery to do the work themselves.

A consultant told us: For goodness sake, don’t use your own names as the brand name. Particularly not yours, Frieda. — Frieda Henskens

“It’s risky,” she says. “But as long as you’re using sound grapes and nothing goes stinky and the lees aren’t stinky, there’s no reason why it can’t work. One of the most important winemakers to me when I visited Champagne while doing my master’s degree in 2011 was Eric Rodez. He told me, ‘Every vintage, do crazy things ... carefully.’ I guess that’s what we’re doing.”

Despite trialling adventurous techniques such as wild fermentation, Henskens and Rankin aim to make top-quality, exclusive sparkling wines – which is precisely what some “experts” told them not to do.

“When we were planning to launch our wines, we talked to a consultant,” says Henskens. “He told us to drop our price and increase our volume. And he said, ‘For goodness’ sake, don’t use your own names as the brand name. Particularly not yours, Frieda’.”

The Effervescence Tasmania festival runs from November 9-17. Rob Burnett

Henskens laughs. Her name comes from her Dutch father, whose roots were in the southern Netherlands, where some sparkling wines are made. So of course she and Rankin put their names on the label.

They have no intention of increasing volumes, either. They have capped annual production of their Vintage Brut at just 2500 bottles, and have stuck to the plan of charging about $100 a bottle for their wines. (Henskens and Rankin both have day jobs – she works for another winery, he’s at the Australian Bureau of Statistics, allowing them to not compromise on their brand).

“We’re selling a luxury product,” says Henskens. “I have no interest in making $35 to $40 sparkling wine. There are already plenty of people doing a good job of that in Tasmania: Brut Elite from Arras, the Pepik that Jeremy Dineen makes at Josef Chromy, among others. The world doesn’t need another one of those.”

Advertisement

What the world does need, though, is more small batches of really special, unashamedly top-shelf sparkling wines like those of Henskens Rankin.

NEED TO KNOW

On Saturday, November 16, Henskens and Rankin will be pouring their wines alongside other top Tasmanian sparkling producers at the Grand Tasting at Josef Chromy Wines near Launceston. The event is part of the sixth annual Effervescence Tasmania festival, taking place at venues across the island state from November 9 to 17. Long winery lunches, vineyard dinners, cellar door tastings, marquee masterclasses and a Bubbles Bar: it’s the ultimate festival for fizz fans. For more info and to book tickets: effervescencetasmania.com

Top Tasmanians

2011 Henskens Rankin Vintage Brut [Tasmania]

Grapes were harvested in the cool, damp 2011 vintage with particularly fresh acidity, so, even after six years on yeast lees and two years on cork, this outstanding sparkling wine is pale, pure and pristine: two-thirds chardonnay, one-third pinot noir, lemony, bright, chalky and long. Delicious. $95

Superlative bubbles from Henskens Rankin: Vintage Brut, Brute Rosé, and Triple Wild Blanc de Blancs.

2013 Henskens Rankin Brut Rosé [Tasmania]

This wonderful sparkling rosé will get its first public outing at Effervescence Tasmania next month, when it will be poured for festival-goers. Like the Vintage Brut, it’s pure and precise, but it also has subtle creamy texture and a lovely rose-hip tang thanks to the wild primary fermentation in older barrels. $100

2014 Henskens Rankin Triple Wild Blanc de Blancs [Tasmania]

It’s extremely unusual to find a sparkling wine that has undergone wild primary, secondary and malolactic fermentation, and in extremely limited production: just 200 bottles made. Extremely good, too: candied lemon peel chardonnay fruit flavours, textural and rich, then bone-dry, almost Vegemite-yeasty intensity to the finish. $110
